abstractText: In this note, I define error exponents and strong converse exponents for the tasks of distinguishability distillation and dilution. These are counterparts to the one-shot distillable distinguishability and the oneshot distinguishability cost, as previously defined in the resource theory of asymmetric distinguishability. I show that they can be evaluated by semi-definite programming, establish a number of their properties, bound them using Rényi relative entropies, and relate them to each other.

1 Introduction to basic operational quantities
sections.text:
The resource theory of asymmetric distinguishability was proposed and developed in [Mat10, Mat11, WW19a, WW19b]. The basic operational tasks are known as distinguishability distillation and distinguishability dilution, in which the goal of distillation is to convert a pair of states to a pure form of distinguishability known as bits of asymmetric distinguishability (AD), and the goal of dilution is to accomplish the reverse task. In both cases, we are interested in these processes occurring as efficiently as possible.
The focus of the one-shot operational quantities proposed in [WW19a] is to fix the transformation error and then, for distillation, to maximize the number of bits of AD that can be extracted from a pair of states, and, for dilution, to minimize the number of bits of AD needed to generate a pair of states. Here, I flip the objective of the task around, and instead place a threshold on the number of bits of AD allowed and then minimize the transformation error that can be realized with this constraint in place. The resulting quantities are known as error exponents and strong converse exponents, similar to what has been studied for a long time in hypothesis testing and information theory [Bla74].

sections.text:

Dεd(ρ, σ) := log2 sup P∈CPTP {M : P(ρ) ≈ε |0〉〈0|,P(σ) = πM}, (1)

It is known that [WW19a]
Dεd(ρ, σ) = D ε min(ρ‖σ), (4)
where the smooth min-relative entropy is defined as [BD10, BD11, WR12]
Dεmin(ρ‖σ) := − log2 inf Λ≥0 {Tr[Λσ] : Tr[Λρ] ≥ 1− ε, Λ ≤ I} . (5)
This quantity is also known as hypothesis testing relative entropy [WR12] and can be computed by semi-definite programming [DKF+12]. By strong duality, we have the following alternate expression for Dεmin(ρ‖σ) [DKF+12, WW19a]:
Dεmin(ρ‖σ) = − log2 sup µ,X≥0 {µ (1− ε)− Tr[X] : µρ ≤ σ +X} . (6)
We can turn the objectives of this task around and define the following one-shot quantities for m ≥ 0:
Emd (ρ‖σ) := − log2 inf P∈CPTP
{ ε : P(ρ) ≈ε |0〉〈0|, P(σ) = π2m′ , m′ ≥ m } ,

Proposition 1 and Corollary 2 below give simpler expressions for these quantities that can be evaluated by semi-definite programming. These simplified expressions are then helpful for establishing bounds on these quantities in terms of Rényi relative entropies (see Propositions 4 and 6).
The idea here is that we are trying to distill at least m bits of asymmetric distinguishability, in the sense of [WW19a], and we would like to minimize the transformation error subject to this constraint. Let us call the first quantity in (7) the distillation error exponent and the second quantity in (8) the distillation strong converse exponent.
For the i.i.d. case, there is an “asymptotic equipartition property” or “large deviation property” as follows:

sections.heading: 1.2 Distinguishability cost
sections.text:
The one-shot distinguishability cost is defined as [WW19a]
Dεc(ρ, σ) := log2 inf P∈CPTP {M : P(|0〉〈0|) ≈ε ρ,P(πM ) = σ}, (15)
and it is known that [WW19a]
Dεc(ρ, σ) = D ε max(ρ‖σ), (16)
where the smooth max-relative entropy [Dat09] is defined as
Dεmax(ρ‖σ) := log2 inf λ,ρ̃≥0
{ λ : ρ̃ ≤ λσ, 1
2 ‖ρ− ρ̃‖1 ≤ ε, Tr[ρ̃] = 1
} (17)
= log2 inf λ,ρ̃,Z≥0 {λ : ρ̃ ≤ λσ, ρ− ρ̃ ≤ Z, Tr[Z] ≤ ε, Tr[ρ̃] = 1} . (18)
The equality in (16) endows the smooth max-relative entropy with its fundamental operational meaning as one-shot distinguishability cost [WW19a].
Eq. (18) clarifies that the smooth max-relative entropy can be computed by semi-definite programming [WW19a]. By strong duality, the following equality holds [WW19a]
Dεmax(ρ‖σ) = log2 sup
t,X,Q≥0,µ∈R {Tr[Qρ] + µ− εt : Tr[Xσ] ≤ 1, Q ≤ tI, Q+ µI ≤ X} .
(19)
It follows that the constraint Tr[Xσ] ≤ 1 can be saturated with equality because the objective function only increases under this change.
For the cost problem, we can turn the objective around, as we did for the distillation problem, to arrive at the following quantities, i.e., dilution error exponent and dilution strong converse exponent, respectively:
Emc (ρ‖σ) := − log2 inf P∈CPTP
{ ε : P(|0〉〈0|) ≈ε ρ,P(π2m′ ) = σ, m′ ≤ m } ,
(20)
Ẽmc (ρ‖σ) := − log2 sup P∈CPTP
{ 1− ε : P(|0〉〈0|) ≈ε ρ,P(π2m′ ) = σ, m′ ≤ m } .
(21)
The idea is that we are trying to use no more than m bits of asymmetric distinguishability to generate the pair (ρ, σ) with as small an error as possible. By definition, it follows that
2−E m c (ρ‖σ) = 1− 2−Ẽmc (ρ‖σ). (22)
Proposition 9 and Corollary 10 give simpler expressions for these quantities that can be evaluated by semi-definite programming. Later on, I establish bounds on these exponents in terms of Rényi relative entropies (see Propositions 12 and 14).
It is then of interest to determine the following asymptotic operational quantities:
lim n→∞
1 n EnRc (ρ ⊗n, σ⊗n), (23)
lim n→∞
1 n ẼnRc (ρ ⊗n, σ⊗n). (24)
See Section 6 for a discussion of recent developments in this regard. Here I also develop basic properties of and establish relationships between the quantities Emd (ρ‖σ), Ẽmd (ρ‖σ), Emc (ρ‖σ), and Ẽmc (ρ‖σ), to treat
them as relative entropies in their own right. For example, each of them obeys the data-processing inequality, which holds by means of an operational argument. This is analogous to how the smooth min- and max-relative entropies have been traditionally regarded as relative entropies, even though their true origin is in the operational tasks of distinguishability distillation and dilution, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3 Relationship to smooth min-relative entropy
sections.text:
Here I establish a direct relationship between the distillation error exponent and the smooth min-relative entropy.
Proposition 7 Let ρ and σ be states and let ε ∈ (0, 1). Then
Dεmin(ρ‖σ) = m ⇐⇒ Emd (ρ‖σ) = − log2 ε. (89)
Proof. For fixed ε ∈ [0, 1], let Λ be an optimal measurement operator for Dεmin(ρ‖σ) = m in (5). Then it follows that
Tr[Λσ] = 1
2m , Tr[(I − Λ) ρ] = ε. (90)
The same measurement operator satisfies the constraints for Emd (ρ‖σ) in (25) and is thus achievable for Emd (ρ‖σ), implying that Emd (ρ‖σ) ≥ − log2 ε.
Now suppose that µ and X are optimal for the dual formulation of Dεmin(ρ‖σ) in (5). Then it follows that
1
2m = µ (1− ε)− Tr[X], (91)
so that the objective function of the dual of Emd (ρ‖σ) in (26) is equal to − log2 (1− λ (µ (1− ε)− Tr[X]) − Tr[W ]) . (92)
Now choosing λ = 1/µ and W = X/µ, we find that these values are feasible for the dual of Emd (ρ‖σ), while the objective function evaluates to − log2 ε. So this implies that Emd (ρ‖σ) ≤ − log2 ε.
Thus, it follows that
Dεmin(ρ‖σ) = m =⇒ Emd (ρ‖σ) = − log2 ε. (93) To see the opposite implication, we can follow a similar method.
The statement above is related to [Ren16, Eqs. (11)–(12)]. It is also stated around [Vaz16, Eq. (4)].
The following is discussed for the classical case in [Ren16], and it has a simple extension to the quantum case. Proposition 8 Let ε ∈ (0, 1) and set m := log2 ( 1 ε ) . Then the following identity holds
2−Ẽ m d (σ‖ρ) + 2−D ε min(ρ‖σ) = 1. (94)
This is equivalent to the following:
Dεmin(ρ‖σ) = Emd (σ‖ρ). (95)
Proof. This identity is essentially the same as that given in [Ren16, Eq. (13)], and it is a direct consequence of definitions. Note that
2−Ẽ m d (σ‖ρ) = sup Λ≥0 {Tr[Λσ] : Tr[Λρ] ≤ ε, Λ ≤ I} , (96)
2−D ε min(ρ‖σ) = inf Λ≥0 {Tr[Λσ] : Tr[Λρ] ≥ 1− ε, Λ ≤ I} . (97)
Thus it follows that
1− 2−Ẽmd (σ‖ρ) = 1− sup Λ≥0 {Tr[Λσ] : Tr[Λρ] ≤ ε, Λ ≤ I} (98)
= inf Λ≥0
{1− Tr[Λσ] : Tr[Λρ] ≤ ε, Λ ≤ I} (99)
= inf Λ≥0
{Tr[(I − Λ) σ] : Tr[Λρ] ≤ ε, Λ ≤ I} (100)
= inf Λ≥0
{Tr[Λσ] : Tr[(I − Λ) ρ] ≤ ε, Λ ≤ I} (101)
= 2−D ε min(ρ‖σ). (102)
The equality in (95) follows from (94) and (9).

sections.heading: 6 Recent developments
sections.text:
These notes were written in June 2020, and all of the results presented in the previous sections were developed at that time. Since then, there has been some interest in the topic of exponents related to smooth max-relative entropy [LYH21, SD22], which are clarified here to have operational meaning as exponents for distinguishability dilution.
In the first paper [LYH21], the asymptotic error exponent for distinguishability dilution, when the error is measured using the sine distance√
1− F (ρ, σ) [Ras02, Ras03, GLN05, Ras06], where F is the fidelity, has been identified (specifically, see [LYH21, Theorem 6]). Therein, the asymptotic error exponent for distinguishability dilution is referred to as the “exact exponent for the asymptotic decay of the small modification of the quantum state in smoothing the max-relative entropy.” It remains open to identify this quantity when using the normalized trace distance as the error.
In the second paper [SD22], a lower bound on the asymptotic strong converse exponent for distinguishability dilution has been identified (see [SD22, Theorem 2]). This bound improves upon the bound given in Corollary 13. It is easy to state a one-shot version of the bound given there using the terminology of this note:

sections.heading: A Background on semi-definite programs
sections.text:
A semi-definite program is characterized by a triple (Φ, A,B) where Φ is a Hermiticity-preserving map and A and B are Hermitian operators. The primal program is given by
α := sup X≥0
{Tr[AX] : Φ(X) ≤ B} , (202)
and the dual program is given by
β := sup Y≥0
{ Tr[BY ] : Φ†(Y ) ≥ A } . (203)
Weak duality is the statement that the following inequality always holds
α ≤ β. (204)
Slater’s condition for strong duality is as follows:
1. If there exists X ≥ 0 such that Φ(X) ≤ B and there exists Y > 0 such that Φ†(Y ) > A, then α = β and there exists a primal feasible operator X for which Tr[AX] = α.
2. If there exists Y ≥ 0 such that Φ†(Y ) ≥ A and there exists X > 0 such that Φ(X) < B, then α = β and there exists a dual feasible operator Y for which Tr[BY ] = β.
Complementary slackness for SDPs is useful for understanding optimal conditions. Suppose that strong duality holds. Then the following complementary slackness conditions hold for feasible X and Y if and only if they are optimal:
BY = Φ(X)Y, (205)
Φ†(Y )X = AX. (206)
